publicationStmt.p: published electronically as part of the TLS project at https://hxwd.org
publicationStmt.availability: This work is in the public domain

sourceDesc.p: Created by members of the TLS project
Comments and notes to 莊子 for translation .

p.seg: 塞 is to "hinder/obstruct", surely not "boost"? I read this very differently than Lynn, the idea is that (following Cheng Xuanying) if one promotes 德 it hinders the natural functioning of one's 性. It appears he is following Wang Shumin's emendation. However, Cheng Xuanying and the earlier commentators straightforwardly read 塞. He is letting the later textual scholarship guide his translation here, despite his claim to read it as Guo Xiang would have.

Lynn reads Zhuang Zhou as casting the blame on these figures, rather than seeing these figures as a cautionary tale of those who pursued 名 and thereby stifled their 性. Zhuang Zhou is apparently casting blame rather than telling a cautionary tale for Guo Xiang: the masses emulate these figures and are thereby led astray.
LXY: 涇, 濁也, 黃河之水, 驟至而濁, 拍滿兩岸, 故曰涇流之大兩涘, 非涇渭之涇也。(NB: LXY parses differently: 涇流之大两涘, 渚崖之間不辯牛馬。) | LYM: 涇，濁也，非涇渭之涇，須辨。
Is this about how many time one heard the dao, or the amount of daos one has heard?
More interpolations. Where does the "still" come in?
The "my own eyes" implies that he has head of the immensity of the Northern Sea before this occasion. This seems an unwarranted interpolation.
More interpolations that are neither warranted neither by the text nor GX's annotation. (Although later commentators agree with the interpretation, LYM: 大方，猶大道也。)
"Just as" is another interpolation. Nothing GX says warrants it.
LXY: 篤於時者, 言所知止一時也 (The suggestion that GX is preferable to LXY often proves unwarranted. Its understanding is confined. This same point is made in chapter one. "Devotion" has odd connotations here.)
"bumpkin scholar" for 曲士 has its charm, though "provincial scholar" seems more accurate. "Bumpkin" has the unwarranted connotation of a hillbilly in the deep south of the US.
LXY: 尾閭, 沃焦也, 出山海經, 言海永至此, 隨沃隨乾。以海比之天地, 但見其小, 豈知其大! 禪家所謂「任大也須從地起, 更高猶自有天來」, 便是此意。

I prefer it being Ruo himself that doesn't know here and in 不知何時止而不盈 above, it fits better with the recurrent themes of 知止其所不知 (ZZ 2?) and 不知吾所以然而然 (ZZ 19?). This stuff just happens without Ruo knowing how or why. Despite being grander than the Earl of the River, he is not preoccupied with himself.
